translated: Moreover, bodhisattvas should thoroughly understand the causes of defilement and purity within all dharmas. Whether it is a cause of defilement or a cause of purity, once they are pure, there is no abiding. That is to say, the arising of mine and views is a cause of defilement, while entering the patience of the dharma of non-self is a cause of purity;
The view of self and mine is a cause of defilement, while inner tranquility and no external activity is a cause of purity;
Desire, anger, and malice are causes of defilement, while loving-kindness, compassion, joy, and equanimity, and entering the patience of observing dharmas, is a cause of purity;
The four inverted views are causes of defilement, while the four establishments of mindfulness are causes of purity;
The five hindrances are causes of defilement, while the five faculties are causes of purity;
The six sense bases are causes of defilement, while the six recollections are causes of purity;
The seven unwholesome factors are the causes of defilement, while the seven factors of enlightenment are the causes of purity;
The eight wrong factors are the causes of defilement, while the eightfold right path is the cause of purity;
The nine grounds for resentment are the causes of defilement, while the nine successive concentrations are the causes of purity;
The ten unwholesome courses of action are the causes of defilement, while the ten wholesome courses of action are the causes of purity.
In brief, all unwholesome thoughts are the causes of defilement;
All wholesome thoughts are the causes of purity.

Whether causes of defilement or causes of purity, all those dharmas are empty by nature, devoid of sentient beings, devoid of life-force, devoid of nourishment, devoid of pudgala, devoid of self, devoid of appropriation, and devoid of action, like an illusion without characteristics, with the inner mind tranquil.

If the inner mind is tranquil, then it is universally tranquil. If it is universally tranquil, then it is the intrinsic nature. If it is the intrinsic nature of dharmas, then there is nothing to be attained. If there is nothing to be attained, then there is no reliance. If there is no reliance, then it is like space.
